body: @dougwilson Could you please assign this to me?
There is no option to assign issues in the mobile version of GitHub.
Oh well. Maybe later :)
I'll be out of middle of nowhere new mexico in a few days. Please make sure this works to publish from Windows please, ad that is the environment I work on and publish from :+1:
@dougwilson Thanks for mentioning it, will test that!
@dougwilson I'm postponing work on this until there is clarity regarding discussion in #2755, as if we decide against using Babel and ES6-ifying codebase, all work on this issue would be useless :)
Gotcha, sorry. Was just trying to go through all my todos now that I'm at a computer and I didn't see you say you didn't want this not assigned to you any longer, very sorry.
Sorry, wrong button clicked.
I removed the assignment ðŸ‘

@dougwilson I've never said I don't want it assigned to me, it actually makes sense to keep it assigned so that someone else doesn't start working on it :). Just provided an update regarding my previous statement of intention to have pr ready this week. If you think that it actually makes sense to work on it, I'm all for it :)
Oops, sorry. I'm confused which user to assign this too -- @kibertoad or @igor-savin-ht can someone confirm?
@dougwilson Sorry for the confusion, this is my work account, while kibertoad is my personal one. Please keep it assigned to kibertoad :)
Is someone is actually working on this? I can give it a shot..
@antoaravinth Not right now, so feel free!

I am not sure that it is a good idea for someone to work on this.  I think we should avoid a transpilation step in express.  I would be hard pressed to be convinced otherwise, but please feel free to try.
See the conversation in this issue, and this comment in particular for my opinions on this: https://github.com/expressjs/express/issues/2755#issuecomment-365011388

@wesleytodd Well, knex.js, which is a very popular library, does the transpilation, and I am not aware of a single bug that was ever discovered to be related to the code being transpiled, so I'm not sure if "chances of a buggy code" is a valid concern. The rest of your points are valid, though.

"Other lib does it" is not going to convince me.  We can start using the features supported in the runtime without transpilation.  And with the timeline we are on now we might even be able to hopschotch right to node 8, so most concerns covered by transilation will be moot.

I don't want to be the one to stifle discussion, but I think this is an idea we should lay to rest as a no.

> "Other lib does it"

It's more about "anecdotal evidence seems to indicate that one of the concerns might not be valid".

> We can start using the features supported in the runtime without transpilation

Wasn't the plan not to use the features not supported by v4 branch before v6 in order to maintain compatibility between v4 and v5 merges?

At the time that conversation made sense.  Now I think it is clear that, unless someone can devote some effort to pushing 5.0 out, we are looking at a timeline which even node 6 will be leaving maintenence mode.  After this message I am going to disengage from this conversation, but unless we can get closer to a 5.0 ready release I think any changes in this area are a waste of effort.

@wesleytodd On this topic in particular (getting 5.x out) I was wondering whether the current development status and missing efforts are documented somewhere. I'd love to see if I can step into and help you guys.

Sure, it is pretty much all here: https://github.com/expressjs/express/pull/2237

Any and all help with these would be great!

@wesleytodd 

Thanks â€” I recall looking at that PR back in the time, but it wasn't really sufficient to understand 

1. What's going on
2. What's missing to have 5.x happen.

For example, `router` and `path-to-regexp` projects have their own issues list and it's hard to get what's required there to have a "code complete" for 5.x

Yeah I can see what you mean.  I think at the moment there is no better way.  Sorry I can't offer more.  I will put on my todo list to go through that list and follow up with a post to make things more clear and centralized where I can.

Thatâ€™d be great. Iâ€™m looking forward to step into some of the outstanding items.

V.
